reviewText: This is the most original show I have seen in a long time. It is an amazing look at what life with a person suffering from multiple personalities could be like. At the same time, a lot of the issues dealt with this in this show every family deals with. It shows the struggle a family faces in defining themselves as a family as well as individuals. A classic in the making. Set your TIVO!

This show is not only entertaining but educational.  I am MPD and have a husband and 4 children (most grown now). My family have watched the episodes more than a few times, pause it, and talk about how that situation has happened in our family and how it has affected each member.  This is the first time that we have been able to communicate how we are feeling and how MPD impacts our lives and relationships.
  I don't think people should critize something they have not experienced first hand.  Being MPD it is easy for me and my family to see her triggers and understand how difficult it is for everyone.

Make no mistake. This is not  a comedy, although there are humorous parts-----just like real life!  This is a story of a family and how they cope (or do not cope) when the only thing that is predictable is that one key person( that affects their lives) is unpredictable. You can gloss over the seriousness by calling Tara's morphing into various personalities a "disorder,"  which would be a disservice.  The impact on almost everyone whose lives she touches, can be totally breath-taking at times, reflecting back to us what many families have and are dealing with everyday when a loved one suffers from any form of mental illness. While there are only three seasons, the ultimate definition of what "Tara" is about, is that it IS a love story, as their son Marshall realizes.  But it is just not a love story of Tara and Max;  it is the love story of family, friends and strangers who keep providing acceptance, forgiveness and understanding to and for the person who needs it most. While Tara cannot seem to "pull herself together," she is the fertile ground that encourages others around her to be the strongest, best, and most enlightened any person could hope to be---making this a better world.

Toni Collette has proven herself over the years to be a solid actor with an impressive range.  I have seen her play comedic, serious, and dramatic roles with the same ease and credibility.  I don't believe she's given the credit she's deserved.  I imagine that her non-traditional looks are the impetus behind that. Who knows?

ABOUT THE SHOW

Plainly put:  Tara has a dissociative personality disorder, better known as having multiple personalities.  Hearkening back to the comment about her range, you can see it here.  She starts off with three personalities:  a hip, school-age girl who competes with the daughter of the family for guys; a redneck, trailer-trash (same difference, I know) man whose primary interests are women and drinking beer, respectively; and a Stepford housewife, complete with anachronistic language and dress styles.  She plays each of these individuals perfectly; you don't see a single trace of Toni in them, and you don't see any credibility conflicts due to bleed-overs, that is, when she's the hip youngster, you really believe it, and when she's the redneck, you really believe it.  Her face aside, you wouldn't know that the same woman is playing these characters.

The rest of the family consists of her husband, a business owner of a landscaping/construction company; her daughter who is positively obnoxious and self-entitled; and her son, who seems like he's the son of the Stepford housewife personality--he's put-together, well-spoken, nerdily dressed, and domestic.  (He makes dinner and enjoys baking.)  Oh, and he's gay, but it's not so much of a focus.  Then there is Tara's sister, who can be described aptly as a walking, roving mess who has self-confidence issues and trends toward promiscuity.  (She even offers to snatch up Tara's husband from her.)

PLOT

Pretty simple:  a family dealing with a matriarch that doesn't quite fit the typical matriarchal role because of her disparate personalities, two of which are impressively disruptive and embarrassing.  The shenanigans affect the family in different ways even though it's clear that they're used to disorder.  The antics bleed over into the school lives of the children and the work life of the husband.

Dissociative issues aside, each family members deals with his or her own issues.  The self-entitled daughter is constantly trying to seek her independence through finding a job, sleeping with guys, and drinking or snorting anything she can get her hands on.  The father is remarkably played and shows both resignation and maturity in dealing with his wife's issues.  He's very laissez faire and rolls with the multitude of punches thrown at him and the family.

The son, Marshall, is played well.  He has the underpinnings of a complex character, but he never arrives there.  The directors keep it simple with him.  What should be applauded is the fact that his sexuality wasn't the thing that ruled his life.  There is an arc in which he falls for a fellow student who is bisexual possibly, but more likely confused.  Other than that, he deals with bullying and life with his unpredictable mother.  Again, well-played and simplistic.

GRIPES

When reading the show's story before watching the first episode, I found the story to be compelling, but I didn't see it as something that could be sustained on a long-term basis.  In other words, there is only so much that you can do with different personalities, even if it's three of them.  (She later develops two others.)  And this is where the show encounters problem inevitably.  By season three, they had run out of ideas, so they started haphazardly injecting new elements into the plot, hoping that something would stick.  It didn't.

For example, at the end of season two, she develops an animal personality, essentially a feral creature that has a penchant for urinating on people and inanimate objects. There's a small arc surrounding how this animal came to be, but you really don't hear much about it after a few of the first episodes in season three.  It was like they put something new out there for the sole purpose to see if people would bite.  If they did, they could then build a greater arc around the character.  If they didn't, they'd move on to something else.

And that's just what they did.  They introduced yet another character, a psychologist who is intelligent and the most self-confident of all her personalities (called "alters" in the show). Tara, her husband Max and their kids, Kate and Marshall appear as your everyday, middle of the road family living in suburbia. They are honest with their feelings, words, and language. They have their issues as any family does. Kate is a teen who thinks and sometimes acts and talks like the teenager you sometimes cringe to see or hear, but also has moments of beautiful soulfulness.  Younger brother Marshall is the quiet, small, incredibly intelligent and wise old man, who is stumbling his way through adolescence. Finding his sexual orientation and place in society is such an interesting, even uncomfortable journey to join him on.
Max, Tara's gorgeous husband seems to be the rock and glue that keeps the family on a somewhat normal path. He loves his kids, and adores his wife. He rolls with the craziness that is his existence.
Then, there's Tara herself.
Tara is a gifted artist who wants to be all and do all for the family she adores. Thing is, in order to be all and do all, a little stress must fall. In order to deal with an unresolved childhood trauma, Tara has developed the only coping mechanism she can handle - Dissociative Identity Disorder (Multiple Personality Syndrome)
Yep, she calls on any one of them when the going gets rough, and they are ALL incredibly unique, weird, and lots of fun to watch. "T" is the 15 or 16 year old who is a saucy little minx, "Allyce" the 50's era vacuum in heels housewife, and "Buck" the kick ass biker dude.

What Toni gives as Tara (+ + +) is nothing short of mind-blowing. USOT is absolutely addicting! You care about all the characters (not just all of Tara's), and you want to (nay, HAVE to) know what happens next with this completely dysfunctional, wonderful family.

I have watched all seasons of this show, I do have DID and I am a writer. Here is something to consider'; if the sensationalism of Tara's DID were removed what would we have? Not much. The conflicts in the show move too rapidly. Tara's alters do not want anything...they have no objective that satisfies their existence. They simply appear at awkward times. There are no stakes in this show. Obstacles are raised and demolished far too quickly, making the characters (the outside ones) flat. The show uses 'colorful and quirky' characters to keep the show interesting, rather than make real characters with real responses. The character of Marshall is gay and that is about it. Isn't there something more to this characted than GAY? The show depends on 'edgy' sexual humor to keep the audience but it is little more than a set up and punch line. Tara's alters appear, run amok then disapper in what becomes boring predictability. The show depends on the sensationalism of Tara's alters rather than writing that uses conflict. What do the characters want (nothing) and what are they striving to acheive (nothing) and there are few scenes that drive the story. This show desperately needs a crash course in Writing. Oh, and yes I was diagnosed five years ago. I do see some events that are somewhat real, but, not too many. Tara's use of many pyschoytopic drugs is foolish. DID treatment does not use drugs. It is 'talk therapy' not drug therapy. I would suggest that viewers start a fund for the writers to take a class with Robert Mc Kee or at least, buy them a personal copy. If we take the alters out, there just isn't anyting left over. Perhaps the poor writing is why the show was cancelled, not jus that 'the viewers were not there,' as stated by Diablo Cody. And, that statement,which is circular reasoning, may be a hint as to why the show had not staying power. Tara could have been a real person, but instead, she was a caricature. For the viewers thinking this show was some kind of liberation for people who suffer with MPD, and the suffering is deep, it fell far short of the mark.

Had it not been for the first two episodes of this series that appeared as extras on "Dexter: Season Three", it probably would have gone unnoticed by me.

However, with the cancellation of "Ugly Betty" and "Desperate Housewives" getting long in the tooth, I was looking for something new and innovative to replace my old staples.

While "United States of Tara" does not appeal to me as much as the aforementioned shows, credit must be given for the outlandishly original premise: Thirty-something housewife and mother Tara Gregson tries to navigate her way through life while dealing with the multiple personalities that take over her body to help her deal with a traumatic teenage experience.

Like most other Showtime series, profanity and sexual situations run rampant here, and the comedy comes out of everyday life, and sometimes from unexpected situations.

I have no complaints about the casting or performances. Everyone involved does a great job. I was thrilled to see the sadly underused Valerie Mahaffey appear as Tara's therapist.

Keir Gilchrist as mature-beyond-his-years teenage son Marshall is probably my favorite character to watch. It's interesting and novel to see how the family just accepts Marshall's gayness for what it is. The show does not go out of its way to make a big deal of the issue.

In contrast, I sometimes cringe when I see how insolent and disrespectful the writers have made daughter Kate. Jaded and possessing a huge sense of entitlement, the character does accurately reflect the current teen generation, but I don't like seeing bad examples being reinforced on TV like this.

John Corbett as the blue-collar everyman just trying to hold this family together, is probably the most underappreciated piece of the pie. You can tell that his Max is really a good guy at heart who is doing the best he can in a trying situation.

One of the series' hilarious laugh-out-loud moments comes mid-way this season when Rosemarie Dewitt as Tara's sister Charmaine reveals a medical mishap to the guests at her birthday party.

Finally, Toni Collette does quadruple duty as the title character and her three alter egos: Foul-mouthed, boy-crazy teenage hellcat "T"; prim, proper and controlling 1950s housewife "Alice"; and male alter, the Jack-Daniels-swilling, porn-loving Vietnam Vet "Buck".

It's interesting to see which persona will inhabit Tara's body in any given situation and Collette must relish a role that offers her so many different opportunities per episode, though I imagine the process must be exhausting.

Half-way through the season, a fourth alter--primal and animalistic--begins to appear. This entity known as "Gimme" wreaks havoc at a health spa and the results are both tragic and hysterical.

While "United States of Tara" is not my favorite show, the premise, acting and writing will have me back for Season Two. Fans of "Weeds", "Nurse Jackie", etc. should definitely check this out.

HA! This show is outrageous, and it is for adults. They swear, talk about sex, drugs, etc. Only once did I ever ponder if it were comparable to the experiances of actual people with DID, and it was the regarding the trauma that caused the split, but I won't go into it so as not to risk spoilers. I'll just say that the discrepancies were rectified by the end of Season One.

Two notable things that I really like about this show:

1) They are taking the gay teenage son character in directions I've never seen before, at least not on a "nongay" genre show. There is no long coming out story arch for him. While that is a very important narrative in every homosexual's life - it's also been done a million times! Nope. This kid is GAY. His parents know it. His sister knows it. His classmates pretty much know it. There is no struggle for acceptance. His gayness is pretty much a nonissue, just one little piece in his entire identity. His "freak" status among his classmates have much more to do with a high intelligence and scrawny build than his sexuality. I don't know if THAT is realistic for a teenage boy in the American MidWest, but I sure would like to live in that world.

2) I can't really think of another TV show where there is a mother-daughter relationship where I can relate to both the mother and the daughter in the same scene. It has been a really long time since I have been able to relate to a teenage character. Maybe this means that she is not realistic either, but a lot of her story transports me right back to those days. And of course I am a mother so I also see it through those eyes, as my own daughter will be there soon, God help me.

Toni Colette is such a powerhouse and chameleon-like actress that a show like "The United States of Tara" is the only way a television show could possibly make the use of her talents. Because she's playing a character with DID, the show allows her to portray four distinct characters, all of which she does with sensitivity, skill, humor, and passion.

Aside from Colette's performance, the other thing that makes the show worth while is that, unlike with Showtime's other half-hour dramedy, "Nurse Jackie", in "The United States of Tara" most of the supporting characters are just as interesting. Tara's teenage children, Kate and Marshall, are especially great characters. So many films and TV shows get teenagers wrong ... either portraying them as miniature adults or cookie cutter stereotypes. But Kate and Marshall are both unique and multi-faceted young people whose reactions to living with a mentally ill parent are believable, funny, and touching. John Corbett, who plays Tara's good guy husband Max, is usually mellow and affable onscreen. But as the season went on, the cracks, frustrations, and flaws that started to show through in the character made him more interesting. Rosemarie Dewitt, another interesting actress, plays Tara's sister, who is equally co-dependent and resentful towards Tara's illness.

All in all, "The United States of Tara" is one of my favorite new shows to come along in a long time, and I'm hoping it sticks around and continues to grow for a while.

Tara Gregson (Toni Collette) is just your average wife and mother. However, she also happens to have three other personalities who are anything but normal. There's Alice, a 50's housewife; T, a 15-year-old wild child; and Buck, a foul-mouthed biker dude. Obviously, this makes for quite an interesting household, as Tara's husband, Max (John Corbett), and two children, Kate (Brie Larson) and Marshall (Keir Gilchrist), try to exist in the same household as Tara's many alters.

In Season 1, Tara decides to go off her medication in an attempt to understand what caused her personality disorder to begin with and to hopefully overcome it. As a result, her various personalities make appearances whenever they feel like it, creating tension within Tara's family and with her sister, Charmaine (Rosemarie DeWitt). This mode of coping isn't easy for Tara, and it has some very dangerous consequences that leave her future in question.

I enjoy this show very much. I've never been a big Toni Collette fan, but she is amazing in this series...I especially love her portrayal of Buck, the Vietnam vet/dirty old man. The show also boasts a very strong supporting cast. Larson and Gilchrist deserve shout-outs for their performances as Tara's two children, who suffer through their own teenage trials and tribulations all while dealing with their mother's mental health issues.

The only part of the show that really rubs me the wrong way is Charmaine. I'm not fond of her character or the actress who plays her. I hope things improve with her in Season 2, or that she doesn't get as much screen time.

Overall, "United States of Tara" is a wonderful addition to Showtime's lineup. I can't wait for Season 2!

I have worked with DID patients for over 20 years and have conducted much research on DID and dissociation. I approached this television show with trepidation because DID has so often been distorted and sensationalized by previous films and television programs. To my very pleasant surprise,the United States of Tara has presented a remarkably accurate portrayal of an admittedly uncommon presentation of DID (i.e., highly visible and public displays of switching from alter to alter). In contrast, the alter personalities of most persons with DID are quite hidden; the alters intentionally avoid public exposure. That said, the creaters and writers of the United States of Tara sought extensive consultation from experts on DID and have done an excellent job of presenting the symptoms, psychological issues, family interactions, and the difficulties in the therapy of persons with DID. Similarly, the International Society for the Study of Trauma and Dissociation, which has provided professional commentary on each episode of the program [...], has consistently found the United States of Tara to be surprisingly accurate (within the limits of a darkly comedic show whose purpose is, of course, to entertain).
